Maybe this is off the topic. 

From above, I see: 

"Vastly (10x - 100x) improved CPU speed with MKLDNN optimizations from Intel." 

Where does "10x-100x" come from ? 

I roughly read the source codes of MKL-DNN before. MKL-DNN trys to employ AVX2 and OpenMP to make things faster, and it will try to generate the operators' codes by using JIT at run-time. By using JIT, it could take some advantages by optimally hand coding some of the operators. It will be faster, but it shouldn't be more than 10x faster. 

If it's really that fast on single machine, I am really wondering what is the cause. Or I missed something important while I was reading the MKL-DNN or mxnet source codes. 

Thanks!

error is computed by metric, not optimizer

``` python
def init_lr_mul(multiplier=1.0):
    tmp_symbol = sym_gen((2, 3))
    # get all parameter list
    internals = tmp_symbol.get_internals()
    arg_names = internals.list_arguments()

    # set lr for all feature layers to 1
    lr_dict = dict()
    for arg_name in arg_names:
        lr_dict[arg_name] = multiplier
    return lr_dict
```

``` python
lr_dict = init_lr_mul(1.0)
# Train a LSTM network as simple as feedforward network
optimizer = mx.optimizer.AdaDelta(clip_gradient=10.0)
optimizer.set_lr_mult(lr_dict)
```

It seems that error is computed by the loss function not the metric. And the problem is that how can we get the error in optimizer.py in each update.

PS: At the end of model definition, usually there would be loss layers like softmax but we can define a different metrics to display the errors. In the optimization process, the error value from the loss layers are used to compute the gradient. Is that right? @piiswrong
gradient is computed by layers. Optimizer only update it. If you want to do something special with the gradient it should be done in a custom loss layer

It seems that the dll file `libmxnet` is wrong?

If you look at the examples, like the one at [1], you see that mxnet already supports having generators in its fit() method and you can simply derive from the DataIter class [2] to make one in python.

Your class should provide the following methods: iter_next(), reset(), getdata(), getlabel(), getindex() and getpad(). As you write those methods, you should cast your data and labels into NDArray objects. For that you can use the mxnet.ndarray.array() function [3] to convert from numpy.

A notable difference with generators for Keras is that Keras expects an infinite continuous flow, while mxnet expects a StopIteration to be raised after each epoch, so make sure that iter_next() returns False when the epoch is over.

Hope this helps!

## 

[1] https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/v0.7.0/example/image-classification/train_cifar10.py#L81
[2] https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/io.py#L99
[3] https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/ndarray.py#L919

Apologize to everyone.
The net do convergence in fact. The problem is the evaluation metric.
The `mx.metric.MAE` doesn't match this net. The `pred` is between 0 and 1 of shape `(batch_size, channels, height, width)`, when compute the update of `EvalMetric`, the right process is, first compute the argmax of `pred` on `axis=1`, then compute the _mae_(or _mse_)
so I defined new `EvalMetric`

``` python
class MYMAE(mx.metric.EvalMetric):
    """Calculate Mean Absolute Error loss"""

    def __init__(self):
        super(MYMAE, self).__init__('mymae')

    def update(self, labels, preds):
        check_label_shapes(labels, preds)
        for label, pred in zip(labels, preds):
            label = label.asnumpy()
            pred = pred.asnumpy()
            if len(label.shape) == 1:
                label = label.reshape(label.shape[0], 1)
            self.sum_metric += numpy.abs(label - numpy.argmax(pred, axis=1).reshape(label.shape)).mean()
            self.num_inst += 1 # numpy.prod(label.shape)
```
Both. Multi-gpu will still provide a speedup compared to single GPU though.
